results.title: Safe in the snow
results.creator_credit: Eric Fullilove, British Petroleum and Cinesound
results.brief_description: The ski rescue service is made up of volunteers, well-trained in search and rescue, first aid and transportation of the injured. Shows the work of the safety patrols in the winter, and sports centres in New South Wales and Victoria. Stresses the need for suitable clothing, well made skis and adequate care when skiing.

results.title: Safe in nature
results.brief_description: Dramatizes two examples of young people getting lost in the woods and in the desert, pointing out what the people did wrong while lost and what they should have done. Information is given on conserving energy and body moisture as well as many other aspects of bushcraft for survival

results.title: Safe harbours
results.brief_description: Herself an immigrant, Karen Adams reflects on how policies and attitudes have changed towards immigrants and, in particular, refugees. A memorial at Otaki reminds her of the potential for hospitality and the dangerous journey that refugees take in the desperate search for safe harbours.

results.title: Safe handling of food in quantity
results.creator_credit: Richard Turner and New York State College of Home Economics
results.brief_description: Discusses food poisoning and measures to prevent it for those employed in handling food. Demonstrates control of bacteria by avoiding contamination, temperature regulation and chemical methods.

results.title: Safe for life (E)
results.creator_credit: Liller Moller, Svend Johansen, Denmark. National Board of Health and Filmforsyningen
results.brief_description: The AIDS epidemic is one which affects both the heterosexual and homosexual community - and being young isn’t a guarantee of immunity, in fact the young are probably one of the most vulnerable groups. Using clever animation, this production broaches the topic of AIDS prevention through the careful use of the condom, the only known way of avoiding the disease. WARNING: THE MATERIAL IS VISUALLY EXPLICIT.

results.title: Safe driving: a question of attitude
results.creator_credit: Pepper Audio Visual, Peter Dimond, Max Pepper and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In a series of dramatised sequences the importance of developing sensible attitudes to driving a motor vehicle is clearly presented. Aggressive and timid drivers, speeding away from traffic lights, poor driving techniques, “tailgating” and drink-driving are all dealt with.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Pepper Audio Visual, Peter Dimond, Max Pepper and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Sadness: a monologue by William Yang
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Tony Ayres
results.brief_description: Based on photographer William Yang’s one-man stage show, ‘Sadness’ is a journey into the past and a heart-breaking testament to the significant traces people leave behind. Through the use of slides, oral history and stylised recreations, Yang investigates the murder of his Uncle Fang Yuen in the sugar cane fields of North Queensland. Running alongside this narrative is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. What emerges is a powerful requiem for the dead and the lasting legacy that family and friends have on the living.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Tony Ayres

results.title: Sadness: a monologue by William Yang
results.creator_credit: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Based on photographer William Yang’s one man stage show, “Sadness” chronicles two diverging narratives through the use of slide photography, oral history and stylised recreation. One story follows Yang’s pilgrimage into the heart of the North Queensland sugar cane fields as he investigates the murder of his uncle Fang Yuen. The other is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. Director Tony Ayres skillfully weaves these two separate stories together creating a powerful testament to family, friends, love and loss. Cinematography by Tristan Milani. Narrated by William Yang.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Ayres, Megan McMurchy, Michael McMahon and Film Australia
results.description: Based on photographer William Yang’s one man stage show, “Sadness” chronicles two diverging narratives through the use of slide photography, oral history and stylised recreation. One story follows Yang’s pilgrimage into the heart of the North Queensland sugar cane fields as he investigates the murder of his uncle Fang Yuen. The other is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. Director Tony Ayres skillfully weaves these two separate stories together creating a powerful testament to family, friends, love and loss. Cinematography by Tristan Milani. Narrated by William Yang.

The other is a series of moving portraits of the many friends and lovers Yang has lost to AIDS. Director Tony Ayres skillfully weaves these two separate stories together creating a powerful testament to family, friends, love and loss. Cinematography by Tristan Milani. Narrated by William Yang.

results.title: Sadness
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
A short animated piece, describing, in pictures and words, a girl’s sadness and feelings of isolation.
